review.title: A Knowledge Compilation Map
review.abstract: We propose a perspective on knowledge compilation which calls for analyzing different compilation approaches according to two key dimensions: the succinctness of the target compilation language, and the class of queries and transformations that the language supports in polytime. We then provide a knowledge compilation map, which analyzes a large number of existing target compilation languages according to their succinctness and their polytime transformations and queries. We argue that such analysis is necessary for placing new compilation approaches within the context of existing ones. We also go beyond classical, flat target compilation languages based on CNF and DNF, and consider a richer, nested class based on directed acyclic graphs (such as OBDDs), which we show to include a relatively large number of target compilation languages.

metadata.title: A Knowledge Compilation Map

sections.heading: 4. Querying a Compiled Theory
sections.text: In assessing the suitability of a target compilation language for a particular application, one can also take into account the conciseness of the formulation, which must be weighed against the totality of questions and transformations it supports in the majority of questions. We limit our attention in this essay to the existence of multitemporal algorithms for answering questions, but we do not present the algorithms themselves. Interested readers are referred to (Darwiche, 2001a, 2001b, 1999), for some of these algorithms, and to the proofs of theorems in other languages. The queries we consider are tests for consistency, validity, implicit expropriation), implications, equivalence, and entative theory.

sections.heading: 5. Transforming a Compiled Theory
sections.text: A transformation, on the other hand, is an operation that returns a modified theory without changing it. A transformation, on the other hand, is an operation that returns a modified theory, which is then operated with the help of queries. Many applications require a combination of transformations and queries.Definition 5.1 (from L to a formula of L that is logically equivalent to L.) Let L be a subset of NNF that is logically equivalent to L 1. Definition 5.2 (from C) Let L be a subset of L that is logically equivalent to L 1. Definition 5.2 (from C) Let L be a subset of NF. L satisfies a polytime algorithm that equals each formula of L to a formula of L that is logically equivalent to L. If a language meets one of the above properties, we will say that it is closed under the corresponding logical terminations.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: The second main contribution of the paper is a comprehensive analysis of more than a dozen languages, for which we have created a knowledge map in which these languages are sorted according to their conciseness and the polytemporal queries and transformations they support. This map allows system designers to make informed decisions about which target compilation language to use: after the class of queries / transformations is decided on the basis of the application of interest, the designer chooses the most concise target compilation art to support such operations in polytime. Another key contribution of this paper is the uniform treatment we have applied to different target compilation languages, showing how they are all subgroups of the NNF language. Specifically, we have identified a number of simple but significant characteristics, including decompilability, determination and determination, that well represent NPI combinations.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This is a revised and expanded version of the paper "A Perspective on Knowledge Compilation," in Proceedings of the 17th International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI '01), pp. 175-182, 2001. We would like to thank Alvaro del Val, Mark Hopkins, Je'ro me Lang and the anonymous reviewer for some suggestions and comments, and Ingo Wegener for his help with some of the topics covered in the paper, which was carried out during a residency of the second author in the UCLA Department of Informatics. The first author was partially supported by the NSF grant IIS-9988543 and the MURI grant N00014-00-1-0617. The second author was partially supported by the IUT de Lens, the Universite ́ d'Artois, the Nord / Pas-de-Calais region within the framework of the TACT-TIC project and the European Community FEDER Program.

sections.heading: Proof of Proposition 3.1
sections.text: The proof of this statement is divided into eight steps. In each step, we prove a number of concise relationships between different languages and then apply the transitivity of the concise relationship to derive even more relationships from it. Linked to each step of the evidence is a table in which we mark all relationships that are proved in this step - we do not display these marks in the very first table. sections.heading: Proof of Proposition 4.1
sections.text: The proof of this statement is divided into twelve steps. In each step, we prove a series of results that are aligned with each step of the proof. Since each step of the proof is a table in which we highlight all the results that are proven in this step, the table of the last step contains all the results that can be translated from this sentence into equivalent s-NNF sentences in polytime (Lemma A.1). sections.heading: Proof of Proposition 5.1
sections.text: The proof of this statement is divided into eight steps. Each step corresponds to one of the transformations in which we prove all results related to this transformation. To show that a language L meets the requirements for CD, we want to show that for each implicit formula L and each consistent term γ, we can construct in each of these languages a sentence that belongs to L and is equivalent to a sentence in the same language. In the case of DNF (resp. CNF), some inconsistent terms (valid clauses) may be fulfilled by conditioning, but these can easily be removed in a polynomial way. - DNNF is sufficient to prove that conditioning preserves decompressibility.

metadata.abstractText: We propose a perspective on knowledge compilation which calls for analyzing different compilation approaches according to two key dimensions: the succinctness of the target compilation language, and the class of queries and transformations that the language supports in polytime. We then provide a knowledge compilation map, which analyzes a large number of existing target compilation languages according to their succinctness and their polytime transformations and queries. We argue that such analysis is necessary for placing new compilation approaches within the context of existing ones. We also go beyond classical, flat target compilation languages based on CNF and DNF, and consider a richer, nested class based on directed acyclic graphs (such as OBDDs), which we show to include a relatively large number of target compilation languages.
